title.narrative: BEHAVIORAL CHANGE FOR OPTIMAL NUTRITIONPRACTICES IN COMMUNITIES

description.narrative: By 2022, adolescent girls, women of childbearing age and family members, including men, and community leaders have knowledge and aptitudes that enable optimal nutrition practices., which contributes to Adolescent Health And Nutrition, Communication And Advocacy, Cross-Sectoral - Human Rights, Cross-Sectoral - Other Programme Areas, Health And Development In Early Childhood And Adolescence, Immunization Services As Part Of Primary Health Care, Mental Health And Psychosocial Well-Being, Nutrition In Early Childhood, Nutrition Of Adolescents And Women, Other Cross-Sectoral Programme Areas, Prevention Of Stunting And Other Forms Of Malnutrition. UNICEF aims to achieve this through Developing And Leveraging Resources And Partnerships, Fostering Innovation And Use Of New Technologies, Operational Support To Programme Delivery, Partnerships And Engagement: Public And Private, United Nations Working Together. This contributes to the following Country Programme result: By 2022, adolescent girls, women of childbearing age (especially pregnant and breastfeeding women) and their children aged 0-59 months adopt better nutrition practices and use quality nutrition-specific and sensitive services.

condition.narrative: Should contribute directly to results for children as outlined in the UNDAF, national results and/or UNICEF Strategic Plan and within the scope defined in the CPD, CPAP, OMP or other agreed upon programme documents

title.narrative: By 2022, adolescent girls, women of childbearing age and family members, including men, and community leaders have knowledge andaptitudes that enable optimal nutrition practices.

description.narrative: UNICEF supported the Government of Burkina Faso on strategic planning and the decree for the commercialization of breastmilk substitutes was adopted. The First Lady of Burkina Faso launched activities related to the celebration of the World Breastfeeding Week 2021. As of the 1st of August, 2021 6,175/17000 CBHW, 17 health districts and 2,486 villages had improved capacity to provide IYCF promotion and counselling services. ;3,132 children from 6 to 23 months received micronutrient powders to improve complementary feeding. | Status:On-track | As-of Date:28/01/2022
